description: This course covers the foundations of statistical machine learning. The focus is on probabilistic and statistical methods for prediction and clustering in high dimensions. Other topics covered include graphical models, dimensionality reduction, neural networks, and reinforcement learning.
name: INTRO ARTIFICIAL INTELL

values.comments:
CIS 520 provides a fundamental introduction to the mathematics, algorithms, and practice of machine learning. Major topics covered include supervised learning, unsupervised learning, graphical models, and reinforcement learning. The course focuses largely on probabilistic and statistical models including naïve Bayes, hidden Markov models, and Mixture of Gaussian models. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning is a required text and selected readings are also assigned throughout the semester.

Most students enjoyed the class and learned quite a bit about machine learning. Some complained that the class was too broad and failed to encompass enough details about certain areas. Others noted that the readings were less than helpful and the lectures were disorganized at times. Many comments also indicated that the homework assignments were too lengthy and very unclear.

On the whole, students greatly enjoyed Professor Ungar’s teaching abilities. Some students described him as “enthusiastic” and “very nice.” He was always available for conversations after class and in office hours and answered emails with helpful responses.

This course targets advanced undergraduates and beginning graduate students in electrical engineering, computer science, mathematics, statistics, and physics. Prerequisites include basic knowledge of algorithms, data structures, and complexity (CIS 320), basic probability and statistics (CIS 261), basic linear algebra, and reasonable programming skills. Programming assignments were completed in MATLAB. One student noted, however, that the course would be difficult for students without “some statistics” knowledge and “a strong linear algebra background.”
